Award.AbstractNarration:
The Partnership for Research and Education in Materials (PREM) between New Mexico Highlands University (NMHU), Morehouse College (MC) and the Georgia Institute of Technology (GT) collaborates on the study and development of organic photonic materials. GT is a partner in the Science and Technology Center (STC) located at the University of Washington. The collaborators explore three areas of organic photonic materials: two-photon absorbing materials, applicable for biological imaging and photodynamic therapy; crystalline nonlinear-optical materials, aimed at designing materials for THz generation and electro optical applications; and the development of new organic polymer materials for solar cell applications. This PREM also focuses on attracting and increasing the number of students in the area of photonic materials.

High school science teachers and community college faculty participate in a 4-week summer workshop to experience bench-top research, design new lab experiments for their classes, and learn about the latest pedagogical tools. In New Mexico, high school students from Robertson and West Las Vegas High Schools are engaged in science education programs like the Dual Credit and GEAR UP programs. Undergraduates from NMHU, MC, and local community colleges perform hands-on research projects in NMHU PREM labs as well as participate in the STC?s well-known Hooked-on-Photonics NSF REU Program. This PREM also provides a summer research experience for 4 NMHU and MC undergraduates at either Los Alamos or Sandia National Laboratory. A major goal of the PREM team is the creation of a critical mass of high school, community college, national laboratory, PREM, and STC faculty partnership-wide mentoring program for undergraduate and high school students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Devision of Materials Research (DMR) supported project “LIGHT – MATTER INTERACTIONS: THEORY AND APPLICATIONS (LMITA)”  for 7 year starting from September 2009 till August 2016. This project was conducted as a partnership between New Mexico Highlands University (Minority Serving Institution (MSI), lead organization), Georgia Institute of Technology (Science and Technology Center, STC) and Morehouse College (MSI). Project contained 3 Research goals. The first goal of the project was related to design and spectroscopic characterization of two-photon absorbing (TPA) materials for photodynamic applications. In realization of this goal were involved several research groups from NMHU,  GATech, and  Institute of Carcinogenesis, Russia. Related studies were also carried out in collaboration with University of Central Florida. Results of these studies allowed identify prodrugs for photodynamic cancer therapy (method of cancer treatment that helps eliminates cancer cell when they are simultaneously exposed to prodrug and laser light).  Another application of TPA materials was related to microfabrication. The second goal of the project was related to creation of organic materials for non-linear optical and electronic applications, as well as design of organic semiconductors and organic conducting materials. Methodology of crystal engineering (combination of two or more components in one crystal) was applied for realization of this goal. Created materials are in process of testing now. Chemical synthesis of materials was carried out at GATech and structural characterization has been done at NMHU. Some synthesized materials demonstrated properties that allow for their applications as field-effect transistors. The third goal was related to creation of organic electron transport materials for solar batteries, light emitting diodes, as well as fluorescent and electroluminescent materials for sensors.

During seven years of NMHU PREM 19 graduate students participated in the project. Six of graduate students, as well as two undergraduate students upon graduation went to Ph.D. programs. At present serval PREM graduates are employed in industry, high school, pharmacy, IT services and other organizations.   As a result of the project PREM partners published 102 papers in the peer reviewed journals, and 136 papers have been presented at notational and international conferences. PREM collaborated with local high schools, giving presentations for K12 students and bringing them into NMHU facilities for brief lectures and demonstration designed to attract young students to materials science. At presents a new cycle of NMHU PREM program was funded by NSF DMR in partnership with the Center for Emerging Materials at Ohio State University.
